Graphical abstract N-doped porous graphite-supported nano-Pt catalyst features a multi-tiered porous structure, anchoring Pt nanoparticles, preventing agglomeration, and enhancing HER efficiency through high surface area and conductivity. Water electrolysis for hydrogen production offers a promising solution to future energy crises and environmental challenges. Although platinum is an efficient catalyst for hydrogen evolution reactions (HERs), its high cost and stability challenges limit its widespread use. A novel platinum-based catalyst, comprising platinum nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped porous graphite (Pt-N-porous graphite), addresses these limitations. This catalyst prevents nanoparticle aggregation, provides a high specific surface area of 1308 m2 g−1, and enhances mass transfer and active site exposure. Additionally, it exhibits superior electrical conductivity compared to commercial Pt-C, enhancing charge transfer efficiency. The Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst achieves an overpotential of 99 mV at 100 mA cm−2 and maintains stable performance after 10,000 cycles. Applied as a catalyst-coated membrane (CCM) in a proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzer, it demonstrates excellent performance. Thus, the industrially synthesizable Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst holds great potential for large-scale energy applications. Keywords Hydrogen evolution reaction Defect-rich porous graphite Superior electrical conductance Spatial confinement Electronic modulation 1 Introduction Currently, fossil fuel energy resources play a pivotal role in meeting global energy demands. However, the world faces significant challenges related to energy supply and demand [1]. The combustion of fossil fuels releases carbon particles, carbon dioxide, and harmful gases such as nitrogen and sulfur oxides into the atmosphere [2]. Consequently, to address environmental pollution and decrease dependency on conventional fossil energy sources, research on various novel renewable energy technologies has become increasingly important [3,4]. Hydrogen gas has garnered widespread attention due to its high energy density and environmental compatibility [5]. Among the methods for hydrogen production, water electrolysis stands out as a key area of research [6]. The efficiency of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is highly dependent on the properties of the cathode catalyst [7]. Effective HER electrocatalysts should possess low overpotentials, small Tafel slopes, and high stability [8,9]. Recently, numerous new catalysts have been explored, including sulfides [10], phosphides [11], nitride [12], and vanadium carbides [13,14]. Despite these advancements, many of these materials suffer from low electronic conductivities and suboptimal d-band centers, which are crucial for achieving high catalytic performance. As a result Pt-based catalysts remain the preferred choice [15,16]. Nevertheless, the limited availability of Pt and the intrinsic limitations of Pt-based catalysts make it imperative to optimize and enhance their structures to improve the efficiency of water electrolysis for hydrogen production [17]. Current Pt-based catalysts have several challenges. (1) Pt nanoparticles tend to dissolve and be corroded during catalytic reactions [18]. (2) Ostwald ripening causes Pt nanoparticles to agglomerate and grow during catalysis [19]. (3) Carbon supports often exhibit poor electrical conductivity and low charge transfer efficiency [20]. (4) Carbon supports have small specific surface areas, limited active sites, and poor mass transfer efficiency [21]. (5) Weak interactions between the supporting material and Pt nanoparticles can cause Pt particles to be detached easily from the support [22,23]. Hence, developing high-performance, durable Pt-based catalysts with enhanced mass transfer and electrical conductivity is essential [24,25]. In this study, we synthesized a Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst using an industrial preparation method. The catalyst exhibits a high specific surface area and excellent electronic conductivity, allowing for the exposure of numerous active sites. This structure facilitates efficient mass transfer and charge transport. Moreover, the porous, defect-rich structure of the Pt-N-porous graphite effectively anchors Pt nanoparticles through spatial confinement effect, playing a critical role in preventing the agglomeration and dissolution of platinum particles. This synergistic effect enabled the Pt-N-porous graphite to deliver outstanding HER performance. Additionally, the scalable synthesis process suggests that Pt-N-porous graphite holds significant potential for large-scale energy applications, positioning it as a promising material in the pursuit of sustainable energy solutions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Graphite materials with a graphitization degree above 94% were used. Ethylene glycol (99%) was sourced from Innochem, chloroplatinic acid (99.95%) from Alfa, and high-purity N2 and NH3 gases from Henan Xingdao Gas Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of Pt-N-porous graphite 1 kg Graphite was placed in a rotary chemical vapor deposition (CVD) furnace (Xianyang Hongfeng Kiln Furnace Equipment Co.). A flow of N2 at 1 L min−1 was introduced, and the temperature was increased over 100 min to reach 900 °C. Subsequently, a water-steam at flow rate of 2 L min−1 was introduced for 2 h to etch the graphite. After etching, the samples were cooled naturally, forming porous graphite. The porous graphite was placed in a crucible and then subjected to heat treatment at 900 °C for 2 h in an NH3 atmosphere, forming N-porous graphite. To synthesize Pt-N-porous graphite, 180 mg of N-porous graphite was dispersed in 200 mL of ethylene glycol, followed by the addition of 5 mL of 0.0386 M H2PtCl6. The mixture was ultrasonicated for 20 min to ensure uniform mixing and then heated in an oil bath at 140 °C for 3 h. After heating, the reaction mixture was filtered and vacuum-dried at 60 °C overnight, yielding the final Pt-N-porous graphite. 2.3 Assembly of PEM electrolyzer The Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst was deposited onto Nafion 115 (DuPont) via transfer printing to produce a catalyst coated membrane (CCM). IrO2 with an iridium loading of 2.0 mg cm−2 served as the anode catalyst, while Pt-N-porous graphite with a platinum loading of 0.15 mg cm−2 served as the cathode catalyst. The proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzer was assembled using two end plates, two bipolar plates, two insulating boards, carbon paper, titanium felt, and a CCM. The bipolar plates featured a parallel flow field area of 3.14 cm−2 (diameter: 2 cm). During testing, deionized water was fed into the electrolyzer at a rate of 20 mL min−1, with the temperature maintained at 70 °C. A Corrtest electrochemical workstation was employed to evaluate the performance of the PEM electrolyzer. 2.4 Computational method Density functional theory (DFT) was employed for first-principles calculations using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [26]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used to describe electronic exchange and correlation effects [27–29]. A uniform G-centered k-points mesh with a resolution of 2π × 0.05 Å−1 and Methfessel-Paxton electronic smearing was used for Brillouin zone integration during geometric optimization. The calculations were performed with a cutoff energy of 500 eV, ensuring total energy convergence to within 1 meV per atom. Structure relaxation continued until all atomic forces were below 10 meV Å−1 and the total stress tensor was within 0.03 GPa of the target value. A vacuum gap of 15 Å was applied to prevent interactions between periodic images. The free energy of the adsorption atomic hydrogen (ΔG H*) was calculated using ΔG H* = ΔE H* + ΔE ZPE − TΔS H* where ΔE H* represents the energy required to adsorb one hydrogen atom, ΔE ZPE is the change in zero point energy, and ΔS H* is the change in entropy. Here, ΔE ZPE − TΔS H* is approximately 0.24 eV; thus, ΔG H* = ΔE H* + 0.24 [30]. The term ΔE H* was calculated as ΔE H* = E(surface+H) − E(surface) − 1/2 E(H2) where E(surface + H) represents the total energy of the selected surfaces with one adsorbed hydrogen atom, E(surface) is the total energy of the surfaces, and E(H2) is the total energy of the gas-phase H2 molecule. 2.5 Material characterization The morphology and elemental distribution of the porous graphite and Pt-N-porous graphite samples were analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU8220) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai F20). Surface elemental composition of the Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-C samples was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific Escalab 250Xi). To elucidate the crystal structure of Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-C, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) equipped studies were conducted using a copper target (K α, λ = 0.15406 nm), collecting data in the 2θ range of 20° to 70° at a scan rate of 5° s−1. The pore size distribution and specific surface area of the samples were measured using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET, Micromeritics ASAP2020) analysis. Raman spectroscopic analysis was performed using HORIBA LabRAM and LabRAM HR800 laser confocal Micro-Raman spectroscopes (laser wavelength: 514.5 nm) to analyze the D-band and G-band in the Pt-N-porous graphite. In situ measurements were performed within the potential range from open circuit potential (OCP) to −0.4 V (vs. Ag/AgCl). Additionally, the electrical conductivity and compaction density of the powders were measured using an IEST 3100 in-situ powder conductivity meter. X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) of Pt L 3-edge were measured at the beamline 4B9A of Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF) in fluorescence mode at room temperature. The energy was calibrated using Pt foil. Athena and Artemis software were used to analyze the X-ray adsorption fine structure (XAFS) data. Finally, the functional groups in the N-porous graphite samples were analyzed using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Thermo Fisher Scientific IS5), providing a detailed analysis of the characteristics of the material. Electrochemical tests were performed using an Ivium-n-Stat electrochemical workstation. HER experiments were conducted in a 0.5 M sulfuric acid solution. A platinum-carbon electrode was used as the working electrode, an Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode, and a Pt wire electrode served as the counter electrode. The potential was calibrated to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) using the equation: E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.0592 × pH + 0.197 V. Catalyst ink was prepared by mixing 12 mg of the catalyst with 3 mL of water and 200 μL of 5 wt% Nafion solution (Dupont, USA). The mixture was ultrasonicated for 30 min and drop-cast onto a Pt-C electrode (surface area = 0.07065 cm2) and left to dry overnight, yielding a Pt loading of 30.3 μg cm−2. For comparison, Pt-C ink (20 wt%, Johnson-Matthey, UK) was prepared with a Pt loading of 54.4 μg cm−2. The catalysts were analyzed using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) at room temperature with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface microscopy of Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts As shown in Scheme 1 , commercial graphite anode materials from lithium-ion batteries were used as precursors. An industrial synthesis pathway was used to prepare porous graphite through water-vapor etching. The furnace was equipped with a 360° rotating mechanism to ensure uniform heat distribution, as shown in Fig. S1. Subsequent nitrogen doping was performed through calcination in an NH3 atmosphere, resulting in the formation of nitrogen-doped porous graphite (N-porous graphite). The final step involved the preparation of Pt-loaded nitrogen-doped porous graphite (Pt-N-porous graphite) through the reduction of H2PtCl6 using ethylene glycol. The materials obtained at each stage are shown in Fig. S2(a–d). SEM images (Fig. 1 a and b) revealed abundant porous channels on the graphite surface, confirming the porous structure within the substrate. This porous architecture is crucial for facilitating catalytic processes. SEM and SEM-energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) images (Fig. 1c and Fig. S3a–d) captured significant Pt loading on the porous graphite surface. The presence of Pt, nitrogen, and carbon elements confirmed the successful synthesis of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst. TEM images (Fig. 1d and e) showed a uniform distribution of Pt nanoparticles on the N-porous graphite support, with well-dispersed Pt nanoparticles and no significant agglomeration. The insets revealed that the average particle size of Pt is approximately 4 nm, a smaller size that provides a larger specific surface area, likely enhancing catalytic performance [31]. The atomic structure of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst, with Pt particles embedded within the defect sites of the N-porous graphite, is illustrated in Fig. 1(f). Additionally, nitrogen doping is evident, with nitrogen atoms bonded to carbon to form pyrrolic, pyridinic, and graphitic nitrogen [23,32,33]. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and STEM-EDS mapping images (Fig. 1g–k) further confirmed the porous structure of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst. The presence of Pt, N, and C elements was clearly identified, highlighting the successful synthesis of the material. 3.2 Internal morphology of Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts To investigate the internal morphological of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst, phenolic resin was used to embed and solidify the Pt-N-porous graphite powder. The treated Pt-N-porous graphite samples were subjected to ultrathin sectioning, and the sections were examined using TEM to observe the internal cross-sectional morphology. Uniformly distributed nanoparticles within the interior of the Pt-N-porous graphite matrix were shown in Fig. 2 (a and b). The EDS line scans on selected particles (Fig. 2c and d) revealed a pronounced Pt signal, indicating the localized presence of Pt nanoparticles within the porous structure of N-porous graphite. Elemental mapping (Fig. S4a–d) confirmed the presence of Pt, C, and N within the Pt-N-porous graphite matrix, substantiating the incorporation of Pt nanoparticles into the porous framework. XPS analysis after etching the surface of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst by 50 nm was shown in Fig. 2(e). The distinct Pt signal, evident even after etching, further confirmed the dual anchoring of Pt nanoparticles within both the exterior and internal porous frameworks of Pt-N-porous graphite [34]. This dual anchoring feature allows the Pt-N-porous graphite to benefit a spatial confinement effect, effectively preventing agglomeration and dissolution of Pt particles and significantly enhancing catalyst durability [35]. 3.3 Structural characterization of Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts The surface elemental states of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst were determined using XPS, revealing the presence of Pt, C, and N, as shown in Fig. 3 (a). High-resolution XPS analysis of the N 1s spectrum (Fig. 3b) revealed three distinct peaks at 398.1, 398.9, and 400.9 eV. These peaks corresponded to the pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic forms of nitrogen, respectively. In contrast, these signals were absent in Pt-porous graphite without nitrogen doping (Fig. S5). The ratio of these nitrogen configurations was calculated to be approximately 0.78:1:0.85. The presence of these nitrogen species modulates the electronic configuration of the Pt nanoparticles, enhancing electron transfer efficiency in the HER and improving the performance of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst [36]. Additionally, this study examined the effects of surface oxidation and the introduction of functional groups on the carbon support during the preparation of a Pt-N-porous graphite, particularly concerning nitrogen doping efficiency. FTIR analysis (Fig. S6a) revealed distinct absorption peaks at 2925 and 3438 cm−1 for porous graphite, corresponding to the vibrations of –C–H and –OH bonds, respectively [37]. Treating porous graphite with concentrated nitric acid at high temperatures significantly increased the –OH absorption intensity, indicating surface oxidation and the introduction of oxygen-containing functional groups. Subsequent exposure of these acid-treated samples to an NH3 atmosphere decreased the –OH absorption intensity. This suggests that the NH3 atmosphere triggers a reduction reaction on the oxidized porous graphite surface, reducing the number of oxygen-containing functional groups and facilitating effective nitrogen doping. XPS analysis also revealed changes in the O 1s signals (Fig. S6b) and the quantity of oxygen-containing functional groups (Fig. S6c) in the porous graphite during acid treatment, consistent with FTIR analysis. High-resolution XPS results for N 1s in porous graphite are shown in Fig. S6(d), where samples treated with concentrated nitric acid show stronger N 1s signal intensity than untreated samples. This suggests that introducing abundant oxygen-containing functional groups, followed by nitrogen doping with NH3 as the nitrogen source, enhances doping effectiveness. This process provides new insights into modifying carbon materials with heteroatoms. The oxidation states of Pt were analyzed using high-resolution XPS (Fig. 3c). Due to spin-orbit coupling effects, the Pt 4f spectrum was deconvoluted into Pt 4f 7/2 peaks (71.4 and 72.2 eV) and Pt 4f 5/2 peaks (74.9 and 77.1 eV), representing Pt and Pt ions (Pt2+ and Pt4+) in Pt-N-porous graphite, respectively. Compared to Pt-C with Pt 4f 7/2 peaks at 71.8 and 73.0 eV and Pt 4f 5/2 at 75.3 and 77.9 eV, Pt-N-porous graphite showed a significant negative shift in Pt binding energy. This shift lowers the d-band center, reducing electron back-donation in the Pt 5d orbitals and accelerating the catalytic reaction process [23,38,39]. Fig. 3(d) and Fig. S7 showed the crystalline structure of the Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-porous graphite catalysts characterized using XRD, respectively. The diffraction peak near 26.3° corresponded to the C (002) plane of the N-porous graphite support. The three diffraction peaks observed near 39.5°, 46.2°, and 67.6° corresponded to the Pt (111), Pt (200), and Pt (220) planes, respectively. Additionally, using the Scherrer formula D = K × λ / (β × cosθ), where K is constant, λ is the X-ray wavelength, β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the diffraction peak, and θ is the diffraction angle, the grain size of Pt-N-porous graphite was calculated to be approximately 3.5 nm, indicating a small crystallite size. These XRD results are consistent with those of conventional Pt-C catalysts, confirming the successful preparation of the Pt-N-porous graphite. As shown in Fig. 3(e), BET analysis revealed that Pt-N-porous graphite exhibits a hierarchical pore structure with micropores (<2 nm), macropores (>50 nm), and an abundance of mesopores (2–50 nm) [40]. Notably, micropores enhance charge regulation, while mesopores facilitate rapid ion transport, provide three-dimensional channels, and buffer space for ion movement [40,41]. Compared with the Pt-C catalyst (198 m2 g−1), Pt-N-porous graphite exhibits a much larger specific surface area of 1308 m2 g−1, offering more active sites and superior mass-transfer capabilities, as shown in Fig. 3(f) [40,41]. As shown in Fig. S8, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-porous graphite are similar, suggesting that the larger specific surface area of Pt-N-porous graphite is mainly due to its hierarchical pore structure. Moreover, the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) adsorption isotherm of the Pt-C catalyst is close to type II, indicating predominant N2 adsorption-desorption in macroporous structures, lacking the hierarchical pore structure of Pt-N-porous graphite [41]. Fig. 3(g) showed the Raman spectroscopy of the Pt-N-porous graphite. Two distinct peaks at 1344 and 1577 cm−1 correspond to the D and G bands, respectively. The D band indicates structural disorder in the carbon, while the G band corresponds to the vibration of sp 2 hybridized carbon atoms. Notably, the 2D peak near 2702 cm−1, a characteristic feature of two-dimensional graphite, further confirms the structural of the supporting material in Pt-N-porous graphite. Additionally, the AreaD/AreaG ratio for Pt-N-porous graphite is 0.27, higher than the 0.23 for Pt-porous graphite, indicating that N doping introduces more defect structures (Fig. S9) [11]. Fig. 3(h) showed the pore size distributions of the Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-C. Pt-N-porous graphite predominantly consists of micropores and mesopores, with a portion of macropores. The abundant multilevel pore and defect structures of the carbon support increase the specific surface area and improve ion diffusion in the catalyst. In contrast, Pt-C primarily features macroporous structures (Fig. 3i), leading to a lower specific surface area and fewer active sites, reducing catalytic performance. 3.4 Performance test of Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts Fig. 4 (a) showed the HER polarization curves of N-porous graphite, Pt-C, Pt-porous graphite, and Pt-N-porous graphite in a 0.5 M H2SO4. Among these materials, Pt-N-porous graphite showed the highest catalytic performance. At 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4b), the overpotentials are 74 mV for N-porous graphite, 32 mV for Pt-C, 34 mV for Pt-porous graphite, and 20 mV for Pt-N-porous graphite. At 50 mA cm−2, the overpotentials are 172, 80, 76, and 58 mV, respectively, with Pt-N-porous graphite exhibiting the lowest overpotential and the highest efficiency. The Tafel slopes (Fig. 4c) indicate that Pt-N-porous graphite (25.8 mV dec−1) has a lower slope than Pt-porous graphite (34.5 mV dec−1), Pt-C (38.2 mV dec−1), and N-porous graphite (70.2 mV dec−1), reflecting superior catalytic reaction kinetics of Pt-N-porous graphite [42,43]. Fig. 4(d and e) presented the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-C in 0.5 M H2SO4 at scan rates from 40 to 80 mV s−1. The CV results showed that increasing scan rate leads to larger electrochemically active surface areas for both catalysts, consistent with previous findings [44]. The double-layer capacitances (C dl) of the Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-C catalysts were determined by fitting the CV curves (Fig. 4f). The C dl, related to the electrochemical surface area (ECSA), is 36.0 mF cm−2 for Pt-N-porous graphite, surpassing the 25.7 mF cm−2 of Pt-C. ECSA was calculated using ECSA = A 0 × C dl / C s, where C s is assumed to be 35 μF cm−2 based on typical reported values [23]. The ECSA of Pt-N-porous graphite is 72.6 cm2 g−1, surpassing the 50.5 cm2 g−1 of Pt-C. This suggests that Pt-N-porous graphite offers a higher ECSA than Pt-C, exposing more active sites and accelerating the HER process [45]. The mass activity (MA) of Pt-N-porous graphite is significantly higher than that of Pt-C at 100 mV, indicating that Pt-N-porous graphite generates higher current density with the same Pt mass (Fig. S10). This advantage is attributed to the defect-rich carbon support in Pt-N-porous graphite. Accelerated durability testing (ADT) evaluated the durability of Pt-N-porous graphite. As shown in Fig. 4(g), the Pt-C catalyst exhibited significant performance degradation after 10,000 ADT cycles, while the Pt-N-porous graphite showed minimal decline, indicating excellent durability for HER catalysis. Notably, replacing the Pt wire counter electrode with a carbon rod during the performance evaluation of Pt-N-porous graphite remained consistent with that of the Pt electrode. This suggests that the superior HER performance of Pt-N-porous graphite is intrinsic to the material rather than due to Pt counter electrode dissolution (Fig. S11). The Pt nanoparticles sizes in Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-C after HER were statistically analyzed to evaluate Pt particle dissolution and aggregation during catalysis. As shown in Fig. 4(h), Pt nanoparticles in Pt-N-porous graphite consistently maintained smaller size compared to Pt-C. Figs. S12–S14 showed that Pt particles size in Pt-C increased from 6.1 to about 6.9 nm after 1000 cycles and to about 7.1 nm after 10,000 cycles. In contrast, Pt-N-porous graphite particles grew from 4.0 to about 4.2 nm after 1000 cycles and to about 4.8 nm after 10,000 cycles (Figs. S15–S17). This indicates that Pt-N-porous graphite effectively maintained Pt nanoparticle dispersion, with minimal agglomeration unlike the pronounced agglomeration of Pt-C. This is attributed to the defect-rich structure and porous characteristics of Pt-N-porous graphite, which anchor Pt nanoparticles and create a spatial confinement effect, maintaining smaller particle sizes. Additionally, after 10,000 ADT cycles, the Pt nanoparticle size in Pt-porous graphite (Fig. S18) increased to 5.1 nm, similar to Pt-N-porous graphite, further confirming that the unique porous graphite helps maintain smaller Pt particles. Fig. S19 showed the structural characteristics of Pt-N-porous graphite after 10,000 cycles. XRD analysis (Fig. S19a) showed that the Pt (111) facet, crucial for high catalytic activity, remained unchanged, preserving the performance of the catalyst. XPS analysis of the N 1s spectra (Fig. S19b) showed that the atomic ratios of pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic nitrogen remained stable at 1:0.78:0.95, nearly identical to the values before cycling. The binding energy of Pt 4f (Fig. S19c) showed no significant shift, indicating a coordination environment between Pt and N. Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S19d) confirmed that the AreaD/AreaG ratio after cycling was 0.28, close to the value of 0.27 before cycling, indicating that the defect structure of the catalyst was well preserved throughout the cycles. These results demonstrate that Pt-N-porous graphite has excellent structural stability, contributing to its outstanding catalytic durability. Additionally, the performance of Pt-N-porous graphite was compared with other reported materials (Fig. 4i). At 10 mA cm−2, the overpotentials for Pt-N-porous graphite, Pt@DNA without a binder [46], Pt-V2CT x [47], Pt/Ni-PCNFs-100 [48], and Pt/Pd/Co alloy [49] were 20, 26, 27, 20, and 35 mV, respectively. At 50 mA cm−2, Pt-N-porous graphite, Pt/Ni-PCNFs-100 [48], PtNSs/S [50], Pt-V2CT x [47], and Pt0.034-MIL101(Cr) [51] exhibited overpotentials of 58, 62, 79, 82, and 122 mV, respectively. At 100 mA cm−2, the overpotentials for Pt-N-porous graphite, Pt-(PtO x )-NSs/C [50], 20% Pt/C [12], PtRu/nitrogen [12], and PtNSs/S [50] were 99, 102, 128, 132, and 150 mV, respectively. Moreover, Fig. S20(a and b) showed the polarization performance curves of Pt-N-porous graphite after iR compensation, compared with other reported catalysts [52,53]. These findings further highlight the competitiveness of Pt-N-porous graphite in HER catalysis in 0.5 M H2SO4 compared to other materials (Fig. S20c). 3.5 Regulation of Pt and N content in Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts To analyze the structural characteristics of catalysts with different element contents, Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts with varying Pt and N contents were synthesized. Four Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts with Pt contents of 0.2, 2.7, 4.0, and 11.1 wt% were synthesized (Table S1). XRD analysis (Fig. 5 a) showed that as the Pt content increased, the intensity of the diffraction peaks for the Pt (111), Pt (200), and Pt (220) crystal increased. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 5(b), Raman spectroscopy indicated a decrease in the intensity of the graphite characteristic 2D peak from 3522 to 2719. This decrease is attributed to the reduction in graphite content and the increase in Pt content in the samples. TEM images of Pt-N-porous graphite with different Pt contents (Fig. S21a–d) showed that the catalyst with higher Pt content has more densely distributed Pt nanoparticles on the support. Fig. 5(c) showed the HER performance of Pt-N-porous graphite samples with varying Pt contents. At 100 mA cm−2, the overpotentials for the samples with Pt contents of 0.2, 2.7, 4.0, and 11.1 wt% were 248, 158, 126, and 97 mV, respectively, indicating that higher Pt content leads to superior performance. Fig. 5(d) showed the nitrogen atomic content in Pt-N-porous graphite samples with doping levels of 1.3, 1.9, and 2.8 at%. With increasing nitrogen doping levels, the negative shift of the Pt 4f 7/2 and Pt 4f 5/2 peaks became more pronounced (Fig. 5e). This negative shift further lowers the d-band center of Pt, reducing electron back-donation from the Pt 5d orbitals and enhancing catalytic performance. At 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5f), the overpotentials for the samples with nitrogen contents of 1.3, 1.9, and 2.8 at% were 119, 107, and 97 mV, respectively, indicating that higher nitrogen doping improves the performance of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst. Additionally, a comparison of Pt-N-porous graphite catalysts prepared with different nitrogen sources (Fig. S22) showed that the catalyst doped with NH3 had the best performance, indicating higher doping efficiency with NH3. 3.6 In situ testing characterization and XAS analysis To evaluate the electrical conductivity of the supporting materials in the Pt-N-porous graphite and commercial Pt-C catalysts, an in situ powder conductivity meter (Fig. S23) was utilized. This device measured the electrical properties of Pt-N-porous graphite and commercial Pt-C [20]. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the conductivity of both materials increased with pressure during testing. This improvement is mainly due to tighter particle contact under pressure, resulting in shorter electron transport paths. Notably, the Pt-N-porous graphite showed significantly higher conductivity than commercial Pt-C. Thus, Pt-N-porous graphite offers superior electrical performance compared to commercialized Pt-C, ensuring efficient electron transport and enhancing its catalytic capability. Fig. 6(b) showed that under various pressures, Pt-N-porous graphite has a higher compaction density than commercial Pt-C. This suggests the potential to fabricate a thinner CCM with shorter proton transport paths using Pt-N-porous graphite. Fig. 6(c and d) showed the in situ Raman spectra of Pt-C and Pt-N-porous graphite in 0.5 M H2SO4, from OCP to −0.4 V (vs. Ag/AgCl). The D and G peaks in both samples indicate the degree of defects and graphitization in the carbon support [54]. The AreaD/AreaG ratio (Fig. 6e) was consistently higher for Pt-N-porous graphite than that for Pt-C. This higher ratio indicates more defects in Pt-N-porous graphite, suggesting more active sites, consistent with earlier C dl analysis. Notably, the AreaD/AreaG ratios for both Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-C decreased with increasing overpotential [55]. This decline in active sites during HER is mainly due to the buildup of H2 on the catalyst surface. The inability to promptly desorb H2 leads to the occupied active sites, reducing their availability for the reaction and impacting critical efficiency in HER [56–58]. To further analyze the chemical state of Pt atoms, XAS measurements were performed. X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) measurements at the Pt L 3-edge were performed to explore the local structure of Pt-N-Porous graphite (Fig. 6f). The white-line intensity of Pt in Pt-N-porous graphite lies between that of metallic Pt and PtO2, indicating Pt oxidation state slightly above 0 but below +4. The Fourier transform of the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectra of the Pt L 3-edge for Pt-N-porous graphite showed peaks at about 2.5 and 1.4 Å, corresponding to Pt–Pt and C–Pt bonds (Fig. 6g). These results suggest that the N-porous graphite support forms a heterojunction with Pt nanoparticles, modulating the electronic configuration of Pt, enhancing electron transfer efficiency, and improving catalytic performance. wavelet transform (WT) of EXAFS analysis at the Pt L 3-edge (Fig. 6h and i) showed two peaks near 8 and 3 Å−1, corresponding to Pt–Pt and C–Pt bonds, confirming this structure [45,59]. 3.7 Theoretical calculations and analysis To explore the impact of the N-porous support for Pt particles in Pt-N-porous graphite, an atomic model was constructed, with detailed in Fig. S24. For comparison, Pt-C and the Pt-porous graphite model were used, as shown in Figs. S25 and S26. The binding energies of Pt particles on commercial Vulcan XC-72 (Pt-C), porous graphite (Pt-porous graphite), and N-porous graphite (Pt-N-porous graphite) surfaces were calculated using the following equation ΔE(binding) = [E(total) − E(surface) − E(Pt)]/N(Pt) where E(total) is the total energy of the system when a Pt particle is attached to Vulcan XC-72, porous graphite, or N-porous graphite surfaces. E(surface) represents the energy of Vulcan XC-72, porous graphite, or N-porous graphite surfaces without attached Pt particles. E(Pt) is the energy of an isolated Pt particle without surface interaction. N(Pt) is the number of Pt atoms in the particles. As shown in Table S2, the binding energies of Pt particles on Pt-C surface and Pt-porous graphite were −0.171 and −2.263 eV, respectively, while those on Pt-N-porous graphite was −2.287 eV. This suggests that the N-porous graphite surface provides greater stability for Pt particles adsorption. Additionally, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis of the electrolyte after HER ADT showed that Pt dissolution in Pt-N-porous graphite was 4.811 µg L−1, significantly lower than the 123.819 µg L−1 in Pt-C. The lower Pt dissolution further confirms that N-porous graphite effectively anchors Pt nanoparticles, consistent with theoretical analysis (Table S3). The adsorption energies of H2O on Pt-N-porous graphite (Fig. 7 a), Pt-C (Fig. 7b), and Pt-porous graphite (Fig. S27) were calculated using the equation ΔE(ads) = E(surface+H2O) − E(surface) − E(H2O) where E(surface + H2O), E(surface), and E(H2O) represent the energy of H2O adsorbed on the surfaces of Pt-C, Pt-porous graphite, and Pt-N-porous graphite, the energy of the surfaces of Pt-C, Pt-porous graphite, and Pt-N-porous graphite, and the energy of a free H2O molecule, respectively. As shown in Table S4, the adsorption energies of H2O on Pt-C, Pt-porous graphite, and Pt-N-porous graphite surfaces are −0.327, −0.467, and −1.189 eV, respectively. This indicates that H2O adsorption on the Pt-N-porous graphite surface is more stable than that on Pt-C and Pt-porous graphite surface. Fig. 7(c) and Fig. S28 showed the electrostatic potential (ESP) of Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-porous graphite, while Fig. 7(d) shows the ESP of Pt-C. Blue areas represent positively charged regions, while red areas represent negatively charged regions. Comparing the three systems shows that when Pt particles are adsorbed on the Pt-C surface, they still exhibit metallic properties (darker blue color). When Pt particles are embedded in Pt-N-porous graphite and Pt-porous graphite, they form covalent C–Pt bonds with surrounding carbon atoms, leading to stronger electron transfer between Pt and carbon. This interaction makes the Pt particles more electron-rich. Notably, the color of Pt-N-porous graphite appears redder than that of Pt-porous graphite, indicating that Pt in Pt-N-porous graphite is in a more electron-rich state. This results in stronger water adsorption on Pt in Pt-N-porous graphite, promoting further H2O dissociation to produce H2. The ESP analysis aligns with the earlier finding that H2O molecules are more effective on the Pt-N-porous graphite surface. Fig. 7(e and f) showed atomic structural models of hydrogen ion adsorption at different active sites on Pt-N-porous graphite, while Fig. S29(a and b) served as a comparison to Pt-C. DFT calculations were performed to understand the enhanced HER activity of Pt-C and Pt-N-porous graphite. The hydrogen evolution activity is closely related to the Gibbs free energy of H* adsorption (ΔG H*) on catalyst surfaces in acidic conditions. Ideally, |ΔG H*| should approach zero, making it a key descriptor for predicting HER activity. In Fig. 7(g), the ΔG H* values for H* near pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen active sites on Pt-N-porous graphite are −0.132 and −0.245 eV, respectively, closer to zero than those on Pt-C (Table S5). Pt-N-porous graphite exhibits superior H* adsorption and desorption capabilities, enhancing its HER catalytic performance. To further understand the enhanced HER performance of Pt-N-porous graphite compared to Pt-C, Fig. 7(h and i) showed DFT calculations of the density of states (DOS). The DOS peaks in Pt-N-porous graphite are less intense than those in Pt-C, indicating stronger electron delocalization in Pt-N-porous graphite, which may facilitate adsorbate desorption. The d-band center of Pt in Pt-N-porous graphite shows a significant downshift compared to Pt-C. A more negative d-band center value weakens the adsorption of reactive intermediates on the catalyst surface. Pt-C typically shows stronger H* binding than Pt-N-porous graphite, which can hinder H* desorption. Thus, the downshift of the d-band center in Pt-N-porous graphite is favorable for tuning ΔG H* to a thermoneutral value (i.e., ΔG H* = 0), a key requirement for efficient HER catalysis. Overall, the effective H* adsorption and desorption capabilities of Pt-N-porous graphite contribute to its superior HER performance [60]. 3.8 Evaluation test of CCM for a proton exchange membrane electrolyzer To evaluate the application potential of the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst in a PEM electrolyzer, a CCM was prepared using this catalyst and the PEM electrolyzer was assembled, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). The configuration of the PEM electrolyzer, from left to right, includes aluminum alloy endplates, polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) insulation plates, bipolar plates, Ti felts, carbon paper diffusion layers, and the CCM. In this assembly, IrO2 served as the anode catalyst, while Pt-N-porous graphite was used as the cathode catalyst. Fig. S30 and Table S6 presented the resistance tests of the PEM electrolyzer using the Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst at a 2 A cm−2 of current density, including the ohmic resistance (R Ω) of 125.4 mΩ cm2, charge transfer resistance (R ct) of 251.2 mΩ cm2, and mass transport resistance (R D) of 188.4 mΩ cm2. Fig. 8(b) showed the polarization performance curve of the PEM electrolyzer. At a current density of 1 A cm−2, the Pt-N-porous graphite electrode exhibited a voltage of 1.98 V, outperforming the Pt-C catalyst, which showed a voltage of 2.03 V. Notably, this improved performance of Pt-N-porous graphite was achieved with a Pt loading of just 0.15 mg cm−2, nearly half that of the Pt-C catalyst. Additionally, the Pt-N-porous graphite electrode demonstrated competitive performance compared to other noble metal catalysts (Fig. 8c), such as Pt-VN (2.13 V) [61], Pd/B3-CNPS (2.11 V) [62], Pt-CB (2.1 V) [62], Au/C (2.58 V) [63], Ru/C (2.01 V) [63], RuO2 (2.57 V) [61], alloyed Pt SA (1.85 V) [61], and Pt-SLP (1.8 V) [61]. Furthermore, the durability test at 0.6 A cm−2 over 150 h showed minimal performance degradation (Fig. 8d), highlighting the excellent stability and structural advantages of Pt-N-porous graphite in CCM for PEM electrolyzer. 4 Conclusions This study synthesized Pt-N-porous graphite using an industrial-scale method. The material features a high specific surface area of 1308 m2 g−1, which enhances hydrogen ion mass transfer. At a current density of 100 mA cm−2, Pt-N-porous graphite exhibited a low overpotential of 99 mV, surpassing similar materials reported in the literature. Its complex pore and defect architecture offer spatial confinement, anchoring Pt particles and effectively preventing Ostwald ripening, thus maintaining particle size over 10,000 cycles with minimal performance degradation. The high electrical conductivity of Pt-N-porous graphite facilitates efficient electron transport, enhancing the HER performance of Pt-N-porous graphite. Additionally, Pt-N-porous graphite showed excellent performance as a cathode catalyst in a PEM electrolyzer, demonstrating its practical application potential. Overall, the combination of high specific surface area, intricate architecture, and excellent electrical conductivity makes Pt-N-porous graphite a highly promising material for HER applications and future industrial utilization. coredata.dc:description: Water electrolysis for hydrogen production offers a promising solution to future energy crises and environmental challenges. Although platinum is an efficient catalyst for hydrogen evolution reactions (HERs), its high cost and stability challenges limit its widespread use. A novel platinum-based catalyst, comprising platinum nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped porous graphite (Pt-N-porous graphite), addresses these limitations. This catalyst prevents nanoparticle aggregation, provides a high specific surface area of 1308 m2 g−1, and enhances mass transfer and active site exposure. Additionally, it exhibits superior electrical conductivity compared to commercial Pt-C, enhancing charge transfer efficiency. The Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst achieves an overpotential of 99 mV at 100 mA cm−2 and maintains stable performance after 10,000 cycles. Applied as a catalyst-coated membrane (CCM) in a proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzer, it demonstrates excellent performance. Thus, the industrially synthesizable Pt-N-porous graphite catalyst holds great potential for large-scale energy applications.
